channel.title: davewiner tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from davewiner.

item.description: I would like the body of a tweet to be an outline.
item.source:markdown: I would like the body of a tweet to be an outline.

item.description:
I watched Breaking Away over the weekend.

First time. The idealistic teen bike rider who worshipped Italian cyclists learns that everyone cheats.

https://t.co/tcep6ldEjo

A hard lesson, one that I never learned, and keep bumping up against.

Maybe bumping is too mild a wordüòÄ
item.source:markdown:
I watched Breaking Away over the weekend.
First time. The idealistic teen bike rider who worshipped Italian cyclists learns that everyone cheats.
https://t.co/tcep6ldEjo
A hard lesson, one that I never learned, and keep bumping up against.
Maybe bumping is too mild a wordüòÄ

item.description: Tonight is the second-to-last Better Call Saul.
item.source:markdown: Tonight is the second-to-last Better Call Saul.

item.description:
1/3 Reviewing the agenda for an upcoming Future of Thinking conference I realize -- if this really is the future -- we lost. Yet another promising tech that is going to be fought over like social media before it, and web browsers before that and PC operating systems before that

2/3 -- winner take all and users be damned. It's not too late to make #toolsforthought a rare exception, where no company can lock their users in, and keep them from switching, where every product has to do everything and therefore does nothing well, and no one has the incentive

3/3 to make their products better and their users more powerful thinkers.

As an elder of this industry, I can't stand by and say nothing, not that I could when I was just a young whippersnapper. For whatever reason I insist on my products being open to competition, and that makes it harder to win, and so be it. That's the way it should be! ;-)

An aside -- I just got a new Pixel 6 Pro. I still have to carry my iPhone 13 Pro with me, because I wear an Apple watch, and use a bunch of other Apple products that don't work with Androids. Left on its own this is the mess the tech industry always creates.

It's only when big-minded devs step in, and they do exist, and force the industry to play on a level playing field. And of course then, they try to subvert that influence.

PS: This thread, annexed to a longer thread, gives a clear demo of how we're piecing together outlines out of our tweets. Oh to be able to edit my tweetiverse in an outliner. Hey I know how to do it. I just have to finish the project I'm working on. Still diggin. ;-)
item.source:markdown:
1/3 Reviewing the agenda for an upcoming Future of Thinking conference I realize -- if this really is the future -- we lost. Yet another promising tech that is going to be fought over like social media before it, and web browsers before that and PC operating systems before that
2/3 -- winner take all and users be damned. It's not too late to make #toolsforthought a rare exception, where no company can lock their users in, and keep them from switching, where every product has to do everything and therefore does nothing well, and no one has the incentive
3/3 to make their products better and their users more powerful thinkers.
As an elder of this industry, I can't stand by and say nothing, not that I could when I was just a young whippersnapper. For whatever reason I insist on my products being open to competition, and that makes it harder to win, and so be it. That's the way it should be! ;-)
An aside -- I just got a new Pixel 6 Pro. I still have to carry my iPhone 13 Pro with me, because I wear an Apple watch, and use a bunch of other Apple products that don't work with Androids. Left on its own this is the mess the tech industry *always* creates.
It's only when big-minded devs step in, and they do exist, and force the industry to play on a level playing field. And of course then, they try to subvert that influence.
PS: This thread, annexed to a longer thread, gives a clear demo of how we're piecing together outlines out of our tweets. Oh to be able to edit my tweetiverse in an outliner. Hey I know how to do it. I just have to finish the project I'm working on. Still diggin. ;-)

item.description:
@KeithOlbermann @marcorubio It seems Marco is beatable.

Maybe that could be a project for Countdown?

Val Demings would make a much better Senator. Wouldn't it be something if the listeners to your podcast could retire Li'l Marco?

https://t.co/wwEsLRVHfp

@KeithOlbermann @marcorubio It's hard to imagine Fox Nudes fighting too hard for Marco.

@jeffjarvis I was curious to see how many times I used the term "in conclusion" on my blog.

The answer is 0.

All occurrences are from guest pieces and published emails. And there are only 8 of those. Almost 28 years of blogging.

https://t.co/SmeW1I8WBC

@jeffjarvis Sorry actually one of them is from me. Oy.
"The average price for a unit of insulin in Canada was $12. Across the border in the US, it's $98.70." https://t.co/ISNtGjZ0EQ
item.source:markdown: "The average price for a unit of insulin in Canada was $12. Across the border in the US, it's $98.70." https://t.co/ISNtGjZ0EQ

item.description:
1/2 I usually exercise in the afternoon, but it's been so hot, so I did my Peloton ride first thing this morning. Then swimming, a nice breakfast with a tall glass of delicious ice coffee. The sense of well-being is overwhelming. I used to have this feeling after working out when

2/2 I was much younger. Now, older, it's harder to get there. It's nice to see if I do everything well, I can still get there.
item.source:markdown:
1/2 I usually exercise in the afternoon, but it's been so hot, so I did my Peloton ride first thing this morning. Then swimming, a nice breakfast with a tall glass of delicious ice coffee. The sense of well-being is overwhelming. I used to have this feeling after working out when
2/2 I was much younger. Now, older, it's harder to get there. It's nice to see if I do everything well, I can still get there.

item.description: @sentin I bought that book when I was just starting out with JS. I should read it again, now that I'm up the learning curve.
item.source:markdown: @sentin I bought that book when I was just starting out with JS. I should read it again, now that I'm up the learning curve.

item.description:
@davekrawczuk yup

also those hockey pucks that help you locate your wallet and keys. i forget what they're called.

i expect i will be carrying my iphone 13 pro with me. ;-)

@whyisjake i totally agree. but in a different thread we're discussing what a tragedy the evolution of javascript has been.

as you know -- i have been exclusively a web developer for almost 28 years!
item.source:markdown:
@whyisjake i totally agree. but in a different thread we're discussing what a tragedy the evolution of javascript has been.
as you know -- i have been exclusively a web developer for almost 28 years!

item.description: @whyisjake Far from perfect but irresistible. ;-)
item.source:markdown: @whyisjake Far from perfect but irresistible. ;-)

item.description:
I agree with Crockford that JavaScript's evolution has only made it worse, but I can't and won't give up on it. I've built a very strong codebase, and I don't use the bloated mess they've added. Further, it can easily be simplified. https://t.co/BLGC4P9ROJ

We should do a profile of JS, A Busy Developer's Guide to JavaScript, and make function calls synchronous by default, and provide an easy way to start a new thread.

With that we can continue to use all the libraries and tools that make it a rich runtime environment.
item.source:markdown:
I agree with Crockford that JavaScript's evolution has only made it worse, but I can't and won't give up on it. I've built a very strong codebase, and I don't use the bloated mess they've added. Further, it can easily be simplified. https://t.co/BLGC4P9ROJ
We should do a profile of JS, A Busy Developer's Guide to JavaScript, and make function calls synchronous by default, and provide an easy way to start a new thread.
With that we can continue to use all the libraries and tools that make it a rich runtime environment.
